summary: This is a motion filed by the co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands, seeking expedited court approval to establish a voluntary claims resolution program (the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program) to address sexual abuse claims against the deceased. The motion outlines the proposed program's structure, administration by independent experts, and its goals of providing a confidential, non-adversarial alternative to litigation for claimants. This document is a court filing and subsequent order from the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands regarding the estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. The Co-Executors of the estate filed an expedited motion to establish a Voluntary Claims Resolution Program, which the court granted. The order directs the Co-Executors to submit the proposed engagement agreement for the Program Administrator and Designers to the court under seal for approval.

keyFacts: The co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate are seeking court approval to create a voluntary, confidential compensation program for victims of sexual abuse, as an alternative to litigation.

Twelve lawsuits involving sexual abuse claims had been filed in New York state and federal courts at the time of this motion, but only one such claim had been filed in the Virgin Islands probate case.

The proposed program would be designed and administered by independent experts Jordana H. Feldman, Kenneth R. Feinberg, and Camille S. Biros, who have experience with high-profile compensation funds like the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund and church sex-abuse programs.
The estate argues the program is in the best interests of claimants and the estate to avoid years of costly, public litigation and to provide timely, compassionate resolution.
The motion states this is the first time a probate court has been asked to approve a mass tort-type program for resolving sexual abuse claims against a decedent's estate.
The Co-Executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate filed an expedited motion to establish a Voluntary Claims Resolution Program on November 14, 2019.
The Superior Court of the Virgin Islands granted the motion, allowing the establishment of the program to handle claims against the estate.
The court ordered the Co-Executors to submit the proposed engagement agreement for the Program Administrator and Designers under seal for court approval.
The legal team representing the Co-Executors includes attorneys from Kellerhals Ferguson Krobian PLLC and other firms.
Magistrate Judge Carolyn P. Hermon-Percell issued the court order granting the motion.
